title: Stored XSS on developer.uber.com via admin account compromise
vulnerability_information:
Hi,

Anyone can add themselves as an administrator on the readme.io uber project that powers developer.uber.com/documentation

To replicate this, first fetch https://uber.readme.io/inactiveand and grab Uber's project ID from the source: 578cd33dc27ce20e004e397b

Then, using this ID, create a normal account on readme.io, verify the email address, log in, and send the following HTTP request:

POST /api/accept-invite/5617f98f7f74330d00dfd86d HTTP/1.1
Host: dash.readme.io
Connection: close
Content-Length: 2
Accept: application/json, text/plain, */*
X-NewRelic-ID: XQEHWF5UGwYHXVlSDgY=
Origin: https://dash.readme.io
X-XSRF-TOKEN:<your token here>
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/51.0.2704.103 Safari/537.36
DNT: 1
Referer: https://dash.readme.io/
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate, br
Accept-Language: en-GB,en-US;q=0.8,en;q=0.6
Cookie: <your cookies here>


The server will respond with "Invite doesn't exist". However, if you go to dash.readme.io you will find that you can now access uber as an administrator. After logging in, I went straight to the users page, took a screenshot as evidence (attached) and removed myself as an administrator. 

Administrators are able to inject arbitrary JavaScript into documentation pages by design, so this could be used for a stored XSS attack on developer.uber.com to hijack developer accounts.

Connection: close
Content-Length: 2
Accept: application/json, text/plain, /
X-NewRelic-ID: XQEHWF5UGwYHXVlSDgY=

activities.message:
Hello, thanks for your report.

Can you elaborate on this report? In our testing we don't see the Uber's project ID in the source code of `https://uber.readme.io/inactive`. Can you point out exactly where you're seeing this?

We greatly appreciate you taking the initiative to contact ReadMe.io about this. That being said, I'm not sure there's much we can do here. This seems to be more of in issue for ReadMe.io to address. 

Thanks and good luck in your future bug hunting.

activities.message:
@albinowax,

Yep, at the time of the report, this is something that could've resulted in XSS on developer.uber.com based on the Readme.IO admin's ability to add arbitrary JavaScript and the fact we were rendering content from them under developer.uber.com/docs.

Since this is mitigated now, we are going to move this to Resolved and will discuss potential bounty awards at our next meeting!

Cheers,
Rob

activities.message:
Hey @albinowax, sorry for the extremely delayed response, I wrote up a comment and it seems I forgot to hit post. 

> I noticed you said you said you "were rendering content from them under developer.uber.com/docs". Are you saying you've stopped doing that now, and aren't interested in future attacks like this one?

It's my understanding (and I've done a quick check of the codebase) that `developer.uber.com` no longer serves content from `uber.readme.io` and is hosted in-house now. As a result we won't pay out for new issues on `readme.io`. Though I'm sure support@readme.io would be interested and we really appreciate the detailed reports that you've sent in so far!

> I'm very happy with this payout and will keep hacking away, but I'm puzzled that this got a lower payout than https://hackerone.com/reports/131450 since the impact is pretty much identical. Did the last report get more because it was a chained exploit or is there a mitigating factor I didn't notice?

As mentioned above, we've now moved `developer.uber.com` off `readme.io`. We were already in the process of doing that when this report was received. In fact, by the time this report reached the developers we had already migrated (hence the jump to `Resolved` state). We decided to pay out this report in good faith since you couldn't have known that when the report was submitted, but paid a slightly lower bounty as this was resolved as a result of an migration that was already in process (i.e. there was no direct patch on our end). 

> Can we publicly disclose this?

Sure thing, approving now.

P.S. We saw your article, awesome work, thanks for the review!
